title: Syllabus
text:
Instructor: Andrew Finley (finleya@msu.edu, Room 211 Natural Resources Building)
Research Assistant: Grayson White (whitegra@msu.edu, Room 211 Natural Resources Building)
Emails: Direct all email inquiries regarding the course and material covered to both the Instructor and Research Assistant, Andrew Finley and Grayson White (both as recipient, or CC‚Äôd).
Links:

The course website, www.for128.org, for course information, lecture slides, and course materials.
D2L, for course feedback and non-public course materials.

Course Description:
This course covers foundational skills needed to work efficiently within a computing environment. The course serves as an introduction to exploratory data analysis (EDA) using the R programming language. Use of R focuses on cleaning, structuring, and enriching raw data to facilitate EDA. The course is designed as a general precursor for subsequent discipline-specific courses. Learning occurs in a hands-on active environment with topics motivated using real datasets from environmental and biological sciences.

title: Syllabus
text:
Instructor: Andrew Finley (finleya@msu.edu, Room 211 Natural Resources Building)
Research Assistant: Grayson White (whitegra@msu.edu, Room 211 Natural Resources Building)
Emails: Direct all email inquiries regarding the course and material covered to both the Instructor and Research Assistant, Andrew Finley and Grayson White (both as recipient, or CC‚Äôd).
Links:

The course website, www.for128.org, for course information, lecture slides, and course materials.
D2L, for course feedback and non-public course materials.

Course Description:
This course covers foundational skills needed to work efficiently within a computing environment. The course serves as an introduction to exploratory data analysis (EDA) using the R programming language. Use of R focuses on cleaning, structuring, and enriching raw data to facilitate EDA. The course is designed as a general precursor for subsequent discipline-specific courses. Learning occurs in a hands-on active environment with topics motivated using real datasets from environmental and biological sciences.

title: Syllabus
text:
Learning Outcomes
Upon completion of this course students should be able to:

apply best practices for naming and organizing files within a directory structure to facilitate an efficient and reproducible workflow,
transform raw data into more readily used formats, i.e., perform key ‚Äúdata wrangling‚Äù tasks such as data cleaning, structuring, enriching, and validating,
conduct basic Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA), i.e., apply built-in and costume written functions to explore data characteristics and communicate findings using summary tables, graphics, and basic summary statistics.

title: Syllabus
text:
Learning Materials & Tools
Textbook: Introduction to Forestry Data Analysis with R, by Andrew O. Finley and Jeffrey W. Doser. Available free, online: www.finley-lab.com/files/ifdar/
R and RStudio: R is a free and open source programming language, and RStudio is an Integrated Development Environment (IDE) which allows for streamlined use of the R programming language. Both are free to install, and installation instructions will be provided in this course. A laptop that can run R and RStudio is required for this course.

title: Syllabus
text:
Meetings & Office Hours
We‚Äôll have a lecture-style meeting twice a week, and a lab meeting once a week.

Lectures are on Tuesdays and Thursdays, 9:10am - 10am, Natural Resources Building, Room 152.
Labs are on Thursdays, 10:20am - 12:10pm, Natural Resources Building, Room 223.

Outside of lectures and labs, I will also hold office hours.

Office hours will be held Tuesdays (10:30am - 11:30am) and Thursdays (1:30pm - 2:30pm), Natural Resources Building, Room 211.
If these times do not work for you, we also hold office hours by appointment. Please email to set up a time to meet.

Office hours are a great way to get help on assignments you are stuck on, ask questions you didn‚Äôt get a chance to ask in class, familiarize yourself with the instructor and course expectations, and much more! Further, office hours can be a very helpful tool for your success in this course and beyond in college. Attending office hours is a great habit!

title: Syllabus
text:
Assessments
In this course, you‚Äôll be assessed based on your work and participation. In particular:

Lab reports (40%)

Lab reports are assigned on Thursdays during lab time, and due the following Wednesday at 5pm on D2L. We will have a lab each week (except for the week of the midterm exam).
The lowest lab grade is dropped.

Midterm Exams (20%)

There will be two midterm exams, one on week 6 and one on week 12. Each midterm is worth 10% of the final grade.

Final Project (15%)

Rather than a final exam, we will have a final group project with project presentations during the final exam time period. More details to come as the semester goes on.

In-class quizzes (15%)

In-class quizzes do not have a regular schedule and will occur based on the material we get through.
The lowest in-class quiz grade is dropped.

Lecture tickets (10%)

Lecture tickets are due at the beginning of every lecture, handed in in-person, by you.
The lowest three (3) lecture ticket grades will be dropped.


Grades are calculated on a four point scale and correspond to the following grade percent:




Grade percent
Grade points




90% - 100%
4.0


85.0% - 89.9%
3.5


80.0% - 84.9%
3.0


75.0% - 79.9%
2.5


70.0% - 74.9%
2.0


65.0% - 69.9%
1.5


60.0 - 64.9%
1.0


0% - 60%
0.0

title: Syllabus
text:
Late work policy

Labs turned in after the deadline will not be accepted unless an extension was granted by the Instructor and/or Research Assistant prior to the deadline. Note though that one (1) lab will be dropped and not counted towards your grade.
If you anticipate not being able to make a midterm, reach out to the Instructor and/or Research Assistant at least a week in advance. Note that midterms will occur during lab time on weeks 6 and 12.
Late lecture tickets will not be accepted. Note though that three (3) lecture tickets will be dropped and not counted towards your grade.
In-class quizzes cannot be made up outside of class. Note though that one (1) in-class quiz will be dropped and not counted towards your grade.
The final project must be turned in on time.

title: Syllabus
text:
Collaboration Policy for FOR 128
Working with your classmates on difficult and interesting problems can not only help your learning, but help you get to know each other. Therefore, we allow and encourage collaboration on lab reports and lecture tickets. However, collaboration on exams and quizzes is strictly prohibited and will be considered academic misconduct.
If you choose to collaborate with a classmate, please add their name to the top of your assignment, and list them as a collaborator, e.g.:
Collaborator(s): Elliot Shannon, Romain Boutelet
But what is collaboration?
For FOR 128, collaboration can look like: working with classmates together on a given problem, doing scratch work, helping each other get un-stuck on a part of a problem, and even coming to a solution. However, you must write up your own problem solutions individually and cannot copy other‚Äôs solutions (even those who you have collaborated with). Further, copying code from a collaborator, classmate, or generative AI tool (see the following section) is strictly prohibited and will be considered academic misconduct.

title: Syllabus
text:
AI Policy for FOR 128
Artificial intelligence (AI) tools, such as ChatGPT, are being used to generate code, analyze data, and much more. However, a key goal of this course is for you to learn how to thoughtfully, ethically, and independently write code and extract knowledge from data. Therefore, the use of generative AI tools, such as ChatGPT and others, are strictly prohibited in any stage of the work process for this course. If you have questions about whether a tool is allowed for this course, ask the Instructor before using it.
Violations of this policy are considered academic misconduct.

title: Functions
text:
Vectors
Consider the vectors:

names <- c("Western red cedar", "Douglas-fir", "Pacific madrone")
ages <- c(NA, 120, 82)
conifer <- c(TRUE, TRUE, FALSE)

What are their types?

title: Functions
text:
Vectors
What are their types?

typeof(names)

[1] "character"

typeof(ages)

[1] "double"

typeof(conifer)

[1] "logical"


Why are these different? Aren‚Äôt they all vectors?



‚àí+
00:30

text:
Vectors
What‚Äôs the average age?

mean(ages)

[1] NA

text:
Vectors

[1] NA

mean(ages, na.rm = TRUE)

[1] 101

title: Functions
text:
Dataframes
Consider the dataframe:

my_df <- data.frame(
  names = names,
  ages = ages,
  conifer = conifer
)

my_df

              names ages conifer
1 Western red cedar   NA    TRUE
2       Douglas-fir  120    TRUE
3   Pacific madrone   82   FALSE

title: Functions
text:
Comparison and logical operators
You learned about some very important operators in Chapter 4:


> and <: greater than and less than
>= and <=: greater than or equal to and less than or equal to
== and !=: equal to and not equal to
&: and
|: or
%in%: in

title: Functions
text:
Comparison and logical operators
Remember, we can use these operators to subset vectors and dataframes:
In ages, get all ages that are greater than 82


[1]  NA 120  82



‚àí+
01:00

text:

Remember, we can use these operators to subset vectors and dataframes:
In ages, get all ages that are greater than 82

ages[ages > 82]

[1]  NA 120

text:
Comparison and logical operators
Remember, we can use these operators to subset vectors and dataframes:
In ages, get all ages that are greater than 82

ages[ages > 82]

[1]  NA 120


What‚Äôs going on with that NA? Try:

ages[ages > 82 & !is.na(ages)]

[1] 120

3 Pacific madrone   82   FALSE

title: Functions
text:
Example: write.csv()

write.csv(
  x = dataset,
  file = "path/to/output.csv"
)



x and file are arguments supplied to the write.csv() function.
Functions in R fall into three categories:

Already built-in functions like read.csv(),
functions from packages that you install onto your computer, and
entirely custom function built by you!

title: Functions
text: Built-in ‚Äòbase‚Äô functions

title: Functions
text: Functions from packages you install

title: Functions
text: Custom functions built by you!

title: Functions
Functions
Functions
Functions
Functions
text:
Writing a(n interesting) function

pow <- function(x, v) {
  result <- x^v
  return(result)
}



What does the pow() function do?
What arguments does pow() take?
What will pow(5, 2) return?
What will pow(v = 5, x = 2) return?
What will pow("ten", "two") return?
What will pow(x = 5, z = 2) return?





‚àí+
02:00

title: Functions
text:
pow() test

pow(5, 2)

[1] 25

title: Functions
text:
pow() test

pow(5, 2)

[1] 25

pow(v = 5, x = 2)

[1] 32

pow("ten", "two")

Error in x^v: non-numeric argument to binary operator

title: Functions
text:
pow() test

pow(5, 2)

[1] 25

pow(v = 5, x = 2)

[1] 32

pow("ten", "two")

Error in x^v: non-numeric argument to binary operator

pow(x = 5, z = 2)

Error in pow(x = 5, z = 2): unused argument (z = 2)

title: Functions
text:
Errors
Consider the following errors:

pow("ten", "two")

Error in x^v: non-numeric argument to binary operator

pow(x = 5, z = 2)

Error in pow(x = 5, z = 2): unused argument (z = 2)




What do/don‚Äôt you like about each error?
Which error message is better? Why?





‚àí+
02:00

title: Functions
Functions
text:
Testing pow() vs.¬†new_pow()

pow("ten", "two")

Error in x^v: non-numeric argument to binary operator

new_pow("ten", "two")

Error in new_pow("ten", "two"): The x argument value should be numeric.

title: Functions
text:
Testing pow() vs.¬†new_pow()

pow("ten", "two")

Error in x^v: non-numeric argument to binary operator

new_pow("ten", "two")

Error in new_pow("ten", "two"): The x argument value should be numeric.

new_pow(10, "two")

Error in new_pow(10, "two"): The v argument value should be numeric.

title: Functions
text:
Testing pow() vs.¬†new_pow()

pow("ten", "two")

Error in x^v: non-numeric argument to binary operator

new_pow("ten", "two")

Error in new_pow("ten", "two"): The x argument value should be numeric.

new_pow(10, "two")

Error in new_pow(10, "two"): The v argument value should be numeric.

new_pow(10, 2)

[1] 100

title: Data Structures: Vectors
text:
Agenda

Overview of data structures
A tour of vectors

title: Data Structures: Vectors
text:
Data structures

A data structure is a format for organizing and storing data. The structure is designed so that data can be accessed and worked with in specific ways.
Structures are either homogeneous or heterogeneous, which describes the data types they hold (one type versus multiple types).
Structures can also be characterized by their dimensionality, see Table Table¬†1.



Table¬†1: Dimension and type content of base data structures in R.


Dimension
Homogeneous
Heterogeneous




1
Atomic vector
List


2
Matrix
Data frame


N
Array

title: Data Structures: Vectors
text:
Data structures

Let‚Äôs take a look at vectors.qmd.

title: Intro to Practical Computing
text:
Last week

Syllabus
Lab 1
Tools for the course: R, RStudio, and Quarto

title: Intro to Practical Computing
text:
Syllabus


Recall lecture tickets are due in person at the beginning of lecture.

Course late policy has been added to online version.
Let‚Äôs quickly review the late policy.

title: Intro to Practical Computing
text:
Lab 1


If you‚Äôre having troubles, technical or otherwise, come to office hours.
Make sure to turn in (.pdf and .qmd) to D2L by 5pm on Wednesday (tomorrow).

title: Intro to Practical Computing
text:
Data Science Tools


R is a programming language.
RStudio is an IDE (what we use to interact with R and our computer).
Quarto is a markdown language, for writing reports.

title: Intro to Practical Computing
text:
Practical computing


Understanding your computer and its file system is vital to success in this class and beyond.
Last week, we threw you into the deep end with data science tools.
This week, we‚Äôll spend a bit more time on the details to help you interact with your computer and these tools.
Today, we‚Äôll focus on file systems and file/folder naming.

title: Intro to Practical Computing
text:
Naming files and folders
Some best practices are important for naming files and folders:


Use consistent casing:

delimiter naming, e.g.¬†lab_01.qmd or cat_pictures
camel case, e.g., finalProjectMaterials.qmd or catPictures

Name your files and folders clearly, concisely, and informatively:

Good: for128_f24
Bad: my_work_for_forestry128_in_fall_2024
Really bad: myWorkFor_forestry128_inFall_2024

title: Intro to Practical Computing
text:
File systems / directories


Every time you create or download a file, you are storing it somewhere in your computer‚Äôs file system.
But where? ü§î

title: Intro to Practical Computing
text:
File systems / directories

Think of your computer‚Äôs file system as a tree

title: Intro to Practical Computing
text:
The root
The root directory is the start or base of your file system.


On Windows, the root is C:/
On macOS and Linux, the root is /

title: Intro to Practical Computing
text:
Your home directory
When interacting with your computer, you are logged in as a user. Each user has a home directory.
For example:


On Windows, C:/Users/Sarah
On macOS and Linux, /home/sarah

title: Intro to Practical Computing
text:
Your home directory
It is often easier to use a shortcut to access your home directory: ~. On Windows, macOS, and Linux, you can use ~ to access your home directory:

~ is equivalent to C:/Users/Sarah and /home/sarah

title: Intro to Practical Computing
text:
Paths
C:/Users/Sarah and /home/sarah are examples of paths. In particular, these are paths to Sarah‚Äôs home directory.

title: Intro to Practical Computing
text:
Paths


Paths specify the location of a file or folder on your computer, let‚Äôs look at a few examples:

/
/home/sarah
/home/sarah/Desktop
/home/sarah/Documents/for128/lab_01.qmd
~/Documents/for128/lab_01.qmd

title: Intro to Practical Computing
text:
Paths

Equivalent paths, on Windows:

C:/
C:/Users/Sarah
C:/Users/Sarah/Desktop
C:/Users/Sarah/Documents/for128/lab_01.qmd
~/Documents/for128/lab_01.qmd

title: Intro to Practical Computing
text:
Relative vs.¬†absolute paths


So far, we‚Äôve only shown absolute paths.
Absolute paths show a file or folder in reference to your computer‚Äôs file system.
Relative paths, on the other hand, show a file or folder in relation to a working directory.

title: Intro to Practical Computing
text:
Working directory example


Recall the absolute path to lab_01.qmd:

/home/sarah/Documents/for128/lab_01.qmd

Say our working directory is the documents folder:

/home/sarah/Documents

Then the relative path to lab_01.qmd is:

for128/lab_01.qmd

title: Intro to Practical Computing
text:
Why?


Reproducibility!

They will work on any computer, not just your own.

Clear and concise.
But really, reproducibility.

title: Intro to Practical Computing
text:
What have we learned?


In Quarto, the default working directory is the folder where the quarto document lives.

Crucial note: this may be different than the working directory in your R console.

You can set your working directory in R with setwd()

Just for your R console, though. This does not apply to Quarto documents.

You can get your current working directory in R with getwd()

title: Intro to Practical Computing
text:
Next time

Remember, lab 1 is due tomorrow at 5pm on D2L.
RStudio projects.
Reading and writing data.

title: Welcome to FOR 128!
text:
Engagement



It has become harder and harder to stay focused over the last decade given the massive rise in wearable and mobile technology.
If you‚Äôll be using a laptop to take notes, please avoid distractions to yourself and classmates by silencing notifications and avoiding checking emails, news, social media, etc.
Please leave your phone on silent and put it somewhere where it won‚Äôt distract you.

title: Welcome to FOR 128!
text:
About me


I‚Äôm Grayson, a PhD student in Forestry.
Before coming to Michigan State, I worked as a Data Scientist contracting for the USDA Forest Service.
Before that, I majored in Mathematics & Statistics at Reed College.

title: Welcome to FOR 128!
text:
About me


I ‚ù§Ô∏è teaching, especially about Data Science + Forestry.
In the past, I‚Äôve co-directed a Forestry Data Science lab for undergraduates.

title: Welcome to FOR 128!
text:
About me

I ‚ù§Ô∏è teaching, especially about Data Science + Forestry.
In the past, I‚Äôve co-directed a Forestry Data Science lab for undergraduates.

title: Welcome to FOR 128!
text:
Path to Forestry Data Science


Take this class and engage thoughtfully with the material. ‚úÖ
Take FOR 372 (offered this spring) to gain more domain-specific statistical expertise.
A wide variety of knowledge in statistics, computer science, and your domain field of expertise (forestry) is important.
Engage in undergraduate research opportunities!

title: Welcome to FOR 128!
text:
Course goals


Getting to know your computer and using it thoughtfully

operating systems,
files,
directories,
good naming conventions,
file organization

title: Welcome to FOR 128!
text:
Course goals


Learn how to use a variety of data science tools with forestry applications

The R programming language,
The RStudio IDE,
Quarto (for reproducible reports)

Learn extensive R programming skills

base R and tidyverse approaches
data structures
custom functions
data wrangling & reshaping
beautiful plots with ggplot2

title: Welcome to FOR 128!
text:
Syllabus: Materials
Textbook: IFDAR
Introduction to Forestry Data Analysis with R, by Andrew O. Finley and Jeffrey W. Doser. Available free, online: www.finley-lab.com/files/ifdar/
Technologies: R, RStudio, a laptop
R is a free and open source programming language, and RStudio is an Integrated Development Environment (IDE) which allows for streamlined use of the R programming language. Both are free to install, and installation instructions will be provided in this course. A laptop that can run R and RStudio is required for this course.

The details of the final project will be discussed as the semester goes on.

title: Welcome to FOR 128!
text:
Syllabus: Collaboration


Working with classmates on labs and lecture tickets is perfectly acceptable.
However, please cite your collaborator(s) at the top of your assignment.
Collaboration on exams and quizzes is strictly prohibited.
But what is collaboration?

title: Welcome to FOR 128!
text:
Artificial Intelligence (AI)



‚Äú‚Ä¶a key goal of this course is for you to learn how to thoughtfully, ethically, and independently write code and extract knowledge from data‚Äù
AI tools are being used by others to write code, but as Data Scientists, we must write code responsibly
At this stage of learning how to code, AI tools inhibit learning and understanding.

title: Welcome to FOR 128!
text:
Next time:

Come to class with a laptop
Complete Lecture Ticket 1 before lecture on Thursday.

title: Vectors and Dataframes
text:
Create, subset, and manipulate vectors and data frames.
Practice reading data from external files.
Get some practice writing R scripts.




Create a new directory called lab_03 within your labs directory (e.g., ~/FOR_128/labs/lab_03). In RStudio set lab_03 as your working directory. Download and move the FEF_trees.csv file from the D2L lab page to your lab_03 directory.
Create a new script and save it as lab_03.R (it should save to your working directory).
Now, use our book, help ‚Äúman‚Äù pages, Google, your intuition, and experimentation to describe the behavior of the code in each of the following questions. For each question, write and execute the code in each question then, using a comment #, add notes above the code to describe/define its behavior (see example script lab_03_example.R in the lab‚Äôs D2L page).

title: Vectors and Dataframes
text:
Create, subset, and manipulate vectors and data frames.
Practice reading data from external files.
Get some practice writing R scripts.




Create a new directory called lab_03 within your labs directory (e.g., ~/FOR_128/labs/lab_03). In RStudio set lab_03 as your working directory. Download and move the FEF_trees.csv file from the D2L lab page to your lab_03 directory.
Create a new script and save it as lab_03.R (it should save to your working directory).
Now, use our book, help ‚Äúman‚Äù pages, Google, your intuition, and experimentation to describe the behavior of the code in each of the following questions. For each question, write and execute the code in each question then, using a comment #, add notes above the code to describe/define its behavior (see example script lab_03_example.R in the lab‚Äôs D2L page).

title: Vectors and Dataframes
text:
Questions

Functions and index subsetting of vectors and data frames
Use the code below to create the plt data frame.

spp <- c("tsugca", "tsugca", "betual", "acerru", "pinust", "pinust", "betual", "acerru")
dbh <- c(15, 12, 6.6, 9.3, 28.1, 9.23, 15.3, 11.1)
qual <- c("ugs", "ags", "ags", "ugs", "ags", "ags", "ugs", "ags")
live <- c(TRUE, TRUE, TRUE, FALSE, TRUE, TRUE, FALSE, TRUE)

plt <- data.frame(spp, dbh, qual, live)


plt 
class(plt) 
names(plt) 
nrow(plt) 
ncol(plt) 
dim(plt) 
length(plt) 
plt[2:4,c(1,4)] 
plt[1:3,c("spp", "dbh")] 
plt$qual 
class(plt$qual) 
head(plt) 
tail(plt) 
head(plt, n=3) 
tail(plt, n=2) 
plt.cpy <- plt 
plt.cpy[1:3,1] <-  c("pinust", "pinust", "acerru") 
plt.cpy[1:2,1] <-  c("pinust", "pinust", "acerru") 
plt.cpy$live[8] <- FALSE 
plt.cpy[8,"live"] <- TRUE 
rep("ugs", nrow(plt.cpy)) 
plt.cpy[,"status"] <- rep("ugs", nrow(plt.cpy)) 
!TRUE 
colnames(plt.cpy)[4] <- "dead" 
plt.cpy$dead <- !plt$live 
plt.cpy <- plt[-(1:5),] 
plt.cpy <- plt[-1:5,] 
plt.cpy <- rbind(plt, c("some new spp", 100, "ugs", FALSE)) 
plt.cpy <- cbind(plt, 1:nrow(plt)) 
colnames(plt.cpy)[ncol(plt.cpy)] <- "tree.indx" 
str(plt) 

Read the external data file FEF_trees.csv into R using the read.csv() function and call the resulting data frame fef.

fef <- read.csv("FEF_trees.csv")


dim(fef) 
head(fef) 
tail(fef) 
sum(fef$height_ft) 
max(fef$height_ft) 
min(fef$height_ft) 
which.max(fef$height_ft) 
fef[which.max(fef$height_ft), ] 
fef[which.min(fef$height_ft), ] 
In the previous two labs you did your work in a Quarto document. What are some ways the script you created for this lab are different from the Quarto document?

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
Agenda
Today, we‚Äôll introduce a few important data science tools:

The R programming language
The RStudio IDE
Quarto, for reproducible reports

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
The R programming language: overview


R is an open source and freely available programming language with fully featured graphics.
R is a quite popular language, especially for scientific programming (but it does have lots of industry popularity, as well!).
R is somewhat similar to python in syntax, and is a great first programming language to learn.

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
The R programming language: history


Initially, there was S. Developed by Bell Laboratories in the mid-70s.
John Chambers, one of S‚Äôs primary developers described its purpose as follows: ‚Äúto turn ideas into software, quickly and faithfully‚Äù.
R was developed in the early 90‚Äôs and deals with many of the memory problems that existed in S.
Under the hood, R calls routines from the lower-level FORTRAN and C languages.

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
RStudio


RStudio, or the RStudio Integrated Development Environment (IDE), is a tool we‚Äôll use to run R code, edit reproducible reports, and even navigate our file system.
RStudio was initially released in 2011, and is the most popular IDE for R programming.
Largely, RStudio is a tool to code efficiently and reproducibly in the R programming language.
Let‚Äôs take a look at it!

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
RStudio

RStudio has four panes: source, console, environment, and file manager.

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
What‚Äôs going on here?

rnorm(1)



rnorm() is a function.
1 is the value we gave to one of it‚Äôs arguments.
We can type ?rnorm() for more information about the rnorm() function.
Let‚Äôs check it out!

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
What have we learned?


The rnorm() function takes n random draws from a normal distribution with a center (mean) and spread (sd).

These statistical details are not necessary for this class.

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
What have we learned?

The rnorm() function takes n random draws from a normal distribution with a center (mean) and spread (sd).

These statistical details are not necessary for this class.


We could have written:

rnorm(n = 1)

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
What have we learned?

The rnorm() function takes n random draws from a normal distribution with a center (mean) and spread (sd).

These statistical details are not necessary for this class.


We could have written:

rnorm(n = 1)

Or even:

rnorm(n = 1, mean = 0, sd = 1)

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
Arguments

rnorm(n = 1, mean = 0, sd = 1)



n must be specified for rnorm() to run
mean and sd are optional, but if you don‚Äôt specify them, R will choose for you (in this case, the defaults are 0 and 1).

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
R as a calculator

R includes many mathematical operations, and is a great calculator.


2 + 3 # addition
2 * 3 # multiplication
2 / 3 # division
2 - 3 # subtraction

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
R as a calculator

R includes many mathematical operations, and is a great calculator.


2 + 3 # addition
2 * 3 # multiplication
2 / 3 # division
2 - 3 # subtraction

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
R as a calculator

R includes many mathematical operations, and is a great calculator.


2 + 3 # addition
2 * 3 # multiplication
2 / 3 # division
2 - 3 # subtraction

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
R as a calculator

R includes many mathematical operations, and is a great calculator.


2 + 3 # addition
2 * 3 # multiplication
2 / 3 # division
2 - 3 # subtraction

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
R as a calculator

Functions exists for more complex mathematical operations


log(7) # the natural logarithm
log(7, base = 10) # log base 10
exp(7) # the exponential function
sqrt(7) # the square root function
abs(10 - 17) # absolute value

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
R as a calculator

Functions exists for more complex mathematical operations


log(7) # the natural logarithm
log(7, base = 10) # log base 10
exp(7) # the exponential function
sqrt(7) # the square root function
abs(10 - 17) # absolute value

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
R as a calculator

Functions exists for more complex mathematical operations


log(7) # the natural logarithm
log(7, base = 10) # log base 10
exp(7) # the exponential function
sqrt(7) # the square root function
abs(10 - 17) # absolute value

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
R as a calculator

Functions exists for more complex mathematical operations


log(7) # the natural logarithm
log(7, base = 10) # log base 10
exp(7) # the exponential function
sqrt(7) # the square root function
abs(10 - 17) # absolute value

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
R as a calculator

Functions can be nested in each other


log(exp(7))

[1] 7

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
R as a calculator

Exponents with ^: 2^3 means \(2^3\)


2^3

[1] 8

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
Quarto


Quarto is a markdown language, released in 2022.
Allows you to include code and text in the same document.
Documents output or ‚ÄúRender‚Äù to PDF or HTML (web) documents.
These slides (and the course website!) are made with Quarto.

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
Quarto for reproducible reports


Quarto is a great tool to help us do reproducible science.
What does reproducibility mean?
reproducibility \(\neq\) replicability / repeatability

title: Tools for Data Science
section: A project is reproducible if another person could take your code and data, run the code, and get the exact same answer.
text: A project is reproducible if another person could take your code and data, run the code, and get the exact same answer.

title: Tools for Data Science
section: A project is replicable / repeatable if another person could take the steps to do your project again in their own setting.
text: A project is replicable / repeatable if another person could take the steps to do your project again in their own setting.

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
Objects in R

R can store objects for use later in what we call an environment.


dbh_in <- 40 # store tree diameter (inches)

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
Objects in R

R can store objects for use later in what we call an environment.
Here, we stored dbh_in in our environment, and printed it out to see its value.


dbh_in

[1] 40

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
Objects in R

R can store objects for use later in what we call an environment.
Here, we stored dbh_in in our environment, and printed it out to see its value.
We can use R as a calculator to compute the tree‚Äôs basal area.


BA_in2 <- pi * (dbh_in / 2)^2 # compute tree basal area
BA_in2

[1] 1256.637

title: Tools for Data Science
text:
Next time


We‚Äôll talk about file systems, paths, folders, and navigating your computer.
More advanced features of R as well: basic data structures, variable naming and code formatting, reading/writing data, and more!

title: Reading and Writing Data
text:
Agenda

Quiz 1 review
Navigating your computer
Reading and writing data

title: Reading and Writing Data
text: Recall your computer‚Äôs file system

section: How do we specify the relative path to File_1.csv, if Sarah‚Äôs home directory is C:/Users/Sarah/Documents?
text:
How do we specify the relative path to File_1.csv, if Sarah‚Äôs home directory is C:/Users/Sarah/Documents?

../Archive/Data/File_1.csv

title: Reading and Writing Data
section: What‚Äôs going on with those two dots? (../)  ‚àí+ 01:00
text:
What‚Äôs going on with those two dots? (../)  ‚àí+ 01:00 


Using .. in a file path means ‚Äúgo back a level‚Äù
Example: Say I want to access a file on my desktop:

/home/grayson/Desktop/important_file.pdf

But, my working directory is as follows:

/home/grayson/Documents

Q: What is the relative path to the important file on my desktop?
A: ../Desktop/important_file.pdf

title: Reading and Writing Data
text:
Now consider a different computer  ‚àí+ 01:00 


We have an absolute path to lab_01.qmd:

/home/elliot/Documents/for128/lab_01.qmd

Say Elliot is using the following working directory:

/home/elliot/research/spatio_temporal

Q1: What operating system might Elliot be using?
Q2: What is the relative path to lab_01.qmd?
A1: macOS or Linux
A2: ../../for128/lab_01.qmd

title: Reading and Writing Data
text:
Reading data
In this course, we‚Äôll focus on reading 2-dimensional data (things that look like spreadsheets) into R.

title: Reading and Writing Data
text: Reading data

title: Reading and Writing Data
text: Reading data

title: Reading and Writing Data
text:
Reading data
R includes a variety of functions for reading data efficiently. One of the most common is read.csv().

title: Reading and Writing Data
text:
Reading data
R includes a variety of functions for reading data efficiently. One of the most common is read.csv().
To read data, we first may want to check our working directory:

getwd()

[1] "/Users/graysonwhite/Documents/for128-org/FOR128.github.io/slides"

title: Reading and Writing Data
text:
Reading data
R includes a variety of functions for reading data efficiently. One of the most common is read.csv().
To read data, we first may want to check our working directory:

getwd()

[1] "/Users/graysonwhite/Documents/for128-org/FOR128.github.io/slides"


Then we can find the datasets folder. I‚Äôve kept mine with my labs:

list.files("../labs/")

[1] "datasets"         "FEF_trees.csv"    "lab_01.qmd"       "lab_02.qmd"      
[5] "lab_03_example.R" "lab_03.html"      "lab_03.qmd"       "lab_04.qmd"

title: Reading and Writing Data
text:
Reading data
R includes a variety of functions for reading data efficiently. One of the most common is read.csv().
To read data, we first may want to check our working directory:

getwd()

[1] "/Users/graysonwhite/Documents/for128-org/FOR128.github.io/slides"


Then we can find the datasets folder. I‚Äôve kept mine with my labs:

list.files("../labs/")

[1] "datasets"         "FEF_trees.csv"    "lab_01.qmd"       "lab_02.qmd"      
[5] "lab_03_example.R" "lab_03.html"      "lab_03.qmd"       "lab_04.qmd"      


Now, given our working directory and datasets location, we specify a relative path and load in the data:

fef <- read.csv(file = "../labs/datasets/FEF_trees.csv")

title: Reading and Writing Data
text:
Reading data
We can take a look at our dataset in R:

dim(fef) # dimensions (rows columns) of fef

[1] 88 18

head(fef) # first few rows of fef

  watershed year plot     species dbh_in height_ft stem_green_kg top_green_kg

  leaves_dry_kg

title: Reading and Writing Data
text:
Reading data
read.csv() reads comma separated value (csv) files, but R has the ability to read a massive variety of file types:


read.table() allows you to read file types with different separators like tabs and spaces, rather than just commas.

title: Reading and Writing Data
text:
Reading data
If we wanted to use read.table() to load in FEF_trees.csv, we would run the following code:

fef <- read.table(file = "../labs/datasets/FEF_trees.csv",
                  header = TRUE,
                  sep = ",")

title: Reading and Writing Data
text:
Reading data
If we wanted to use read.table() to load in FEF_trees.csv, we would run the following code:

fef <- read.table(file = "../labs/datasets/FEF_trees.csv",
                  header = TRUE,
                  sep = ",")

title: Reading and Writing Data
text:
Reading data
If we wanted to use read.table() to load in FEF_trees.csv, we would run the following code:

fef <- read.table(file = "../labs/datasets/FEF_trees.csv",
                  header = TRUE,
                  sep = ",")

title: Reading and Writing Data
text:
Reading data: tab separated
We also have the file FEF_trees.tsv, which looks a bit different than FEF_trees.csv.

title: Reading and Writing Data
text: FEF_trees.csv

title: Reading and Writing Data
text: FEF_trees.tsv

title: Reading and Writing Data
text:
Reading FEF_trees.tsv into R

fef <- read.table(file = "../labs/datasets/FEF_trees.tsv",
                  header = TRUE,
                  sep = "\t")

title: Reading and Writing Data
text:
Reading FEF_trees.tsv into R

fef <- read.table(file = "../labs/datasets/FEF_trees.tsv",
                  header = TRUE,
                  sep = "\t")

title: Reading and Writing Data
text:
Writing data


Similar to read.csv() and read.table(), R includes write.csv() and write.table() functions.
These functions allow you to create (or ‚Äúwrite‚Äù) your own files with an R object.
Let‚Äôs take a look!

title: Reading and Writing Data
text:
Writing data
First, we look at the files in my ‚Äúlabs‚Äù folder

list.files("../labs")

[1] "datasets"         "FEF_trees.csv"    "lab_01.qmd"       "lab_02.qmd"      
[5] "lab_03_example.R" "lab_03.html"      "lab_03.qmd"       "lab_04.qmd"

title: Reading and Writing Data
text:
Writing data
Next, we can write the fef object to a .csv file.

write.csv(x = fef,
          file = "../labs/my_fef.csv")

title: Reading and Writing Data
text:
Writing data
Next, we can write the fef object to a .csv file.

write.csv(x = fef,
          file = "../labs/my_fef.csv")

Now, we can see that the file is written.

list.files("../labs")

[1] "datasets"         "FEF_trees.csv"    "lab_01.qmd"       "lab_02.qmd"

title: Reading and Writing Data

Next Week

Andy will deliver lecture and lab through Tuesday 9/17.
Main focuses: Chapter 4 (Data Structures).

title: Logical subsetting vectors and data frames
text:
create, subset, and manipulate vectors and data frames
use comparison and logical operators
practice combining logical tests to extract information from vectors and data frames
start thinking ‚Äúinside out‚Äù

title: Logical subsetting vectors and data frames
text:
create, subset, and manipulate vectors and data frames
use comparison and logical operators
practice combining logical tests to extract information from vectors and data frames
start thinking ‚Äúinside out‚Äù

title: Logical subsetting vectors and data frames
text:
Logical subsetting
So far we have directly specified the elements of vectors that we want to extract, for example spp[1] or dbh[length(dbh)] or spp[c(1,3,5)]. We have also subsetted data frame rows and columns, for example, plt[c(2,5),], plt[nrow(plt),], plt[,1:2], or plt[,c("spp","dbh")]. More commonly we want to extract elements that meet a condition, such as all trees greater than some minimum DBH or all trees of a given species. For this we use subsetting with logical vectors, see Section 6.6 in the course book.
Here are the comparison operators:

Equal: ==
Not equal: !=
Greater than: >
Less than: <
Greater than or equal to: >=
Less than or equal to: <=

Let‚Äôs give these operators a spin using the plt data frame.
First on a single column, i.e., a vector subset operation.

plt$qual[plt$qual == "ags"] # Understand this statement from the inside out!

[1] "ags" "ags" "ags" "ags" "ags"


Get all trees (i.e., rows) for species acerru.

plt[plt$spp == "acerru", ]

     spp  dbh qual  live
4 acerru  9.3  ugs FALSE
8 acerru 11.1  ags  TRUE


Get all trees (i.e., rows) but for acerru.

plt[plt$spp != "acerru", ]

     spp   dbh qual  live
1 tsugca 15.00  ugs  TRUE
2 tsugca 12.00  ags  TRUE
3 betual  6.60  ags  TRUE
5 pinust 28.10  ags  TRUE
6 pinust  9.23  ags  TRUE
7 betual 15.30  ugs FALSE


Get all trees (i.e., rows) with DBH greater than 10.

plt[plt$dbh > 10, ]

     spp  dbh qual  live
1 tsugca 15.0  ugs  TRUE
2 tsugca 12.0  ags  TRUE
5 pinust 28.1  ags  TRUE
7 betual 15.3  ugs FALSE
8 acerru 11.1  ags  TRUE


Get all tree species with DBH greater than 10.

plt[plt$dbh > 10, "spp"]

[1] "tsugca" "tsugca" "pinust" "betual" "acerru"


Find all live trees. Note, why do I have plt$live and not plt$live == TRUE in the code below?

plt[plt$live, ]

     spp   dbh qual live
1 tsugca 15.00  ugs TRUE
2 tsugca 12.00  ags TRUE
3 betual  6.60  ags TRUE
5 pinust 28.10  ags TRUE
6 pinust  9.23  ags TRUE
8 acerru 11.10  ags TRUE

title: Logical subsetting vectors and data frames
section: A bit on logical operators and subsetting
text:
A bit on logical operators and subsetting
There are some logical operators we haven‚Äôt seen yet, including the ‚Äúand‚Äù operator and the ‚Äúor‚Äù operator.

and: &
or: |

The & operator compares vector elements on its left and right to see if they match. If they are both TRUE, then & returns TRUE, otherwise FALSE. The | operator compares vector elements on its left and right to see if either of them are TRUE. If at least one is TRUE then | returns TRUE, otherwise if both are FALSE then FALSE is returned. These operations are applied for each element pair along the vectors. For example:

c(FALSE, TRUE, FALSE) | c(TRUE, FALSE, FALSE)

[1]  TRUE  TRUE FALSE

c(FALSE, TRUE, FALSE) & c(TRUE, TRUE, FALSE)

[1] FALSE  TRUE FALSE


So, say you want all acerru with DBH greater than 10.

plt[plt$spp == "acerru" & plt$dbh > 10, ]

     spp  dbh qual live
8 acerru 11.1  ags TRUE


Another useful logical operator is the ! (i.e., the exclamation point, referred to as the ‚Äúbang‚Äù in coding slang) which negates or flips the logical value, so for example !FALSE is TRUE and !TRUE is FALSE (or !‚ÄúI know what I‚Äôm talking about‚Äù).
Yet another very handy operator is %in% which is used to identify if an element occurs in a second vector. Or a substitute for a series of ‚Äúor‚Äù statements. Consider the example below and consult the manual page via help("%in%").

dbh == 15 | dbh == 6 | dbh == 11

[1]  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE

dbh %in% c(15, 6, 11)

[1]  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE



letters

 [1] "a" "b" "c" "d" "e" "f" "g" "h" "i" "j" "k" "l" "m" "n" "o" "p" "q" "r" "s"
[20] "t" "u" "v" "w" "x" "y" "z"

letters %in% c("a", "m", "q", "s")

 [1]  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE
[13]  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE  TRUE FALSE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE
[25] FALSE FALSE

# letters == "a" | letters == "m" | letters = "q" | letters == "s" ## Find the error.

Say you want acerru and tsugca with DBH greater than 10.

plt[plt$spp %in% c("acerru", "tsugca") & plt$dbh > 10,]

     spp  dbh qual live
1 tsugca 15.0  ugs TRUE
2 tsugca 12.0  ags TRUE
8 acerru 11.1  ags TRUE


Now, say you want acerru and tsugca with DBH greater than 10 and acceptable growing stock.

plt[plt$spp %in% c("acerru", "tsugca") & plt$dbh > 10 & plt$qual == "ags",]

     spp  dbh qual live
2 tsugca 12.0  ags TRUE
8 acerru 11.1  ags TRUE

title: Logical subsetting vectors and data frames
text:
Your turn!

Find all trees with DBH less than 9.5.
Find all trees that are not tsugca (hint use the !).
Find all dead trees (hint use the !).
Find all live trees of unacceptable growing stock.
Find all live betual and acerru that are of acceptable growing stock.
Make up your own subsetting criteria.

title: Functions and conditionals
section: Recall the pow() function from last time

title: Functions and conditionals
text:
pow() test

pow(5, 2)

[1] 25

title: Functions and conditionals
text:
pow() test

pow(5, 2)

[1] 25

pow(v = 5, x = 2)

[1] 32

pow("ten", "two")

Error in x^v: non-numeric argument to binary operator

title: Functions and conditionals
text:
pow() test

pow(5, 2)

[1] 25

pow(v = 5, x = 2)

[1] 32

pow("ten", "two")

Error in x^v: non-numeric argument to binary operator

pow(x = 5, z = 2)

Error in pow(x = 5, z = 2): unused argument (z = 2)

title: Functions and conditionals
text:
Errors
Consider the following errors:

pow("ten", "two")

Error in x^v: non-numeric argument to binary operator

pow(x = 5, z = 2)

Error in pow(x = 5, z = 2): unused argument (z = 2)




What do/don‚Äôt you like about each error?
Which error message is better? Why?





‚àí+
02:00

title: Functions and conditionals
Functions and conditionals
text:
Testing pow() vs.¬†new_pow()

pow("ten", "two")

Error in x^v: non-numeric argument to binary operator

new_pow("ten", "two")

Error in new_pow("ten", "two"): The x argument value should be numeric.

title: Functions and conditionals
text:
Testing pow() vs.¬†new_pow()

pow("ten", "two")

Error in x^v: non-numeric argument to binary operator

new_pow("ten", "two")

Error in new_pow("ten", "two"): The x argument value should be numeric.

new_pow(10, "two")

Error in new_pow(10, "two"): The v argument value should be numeric.

title: Functions and conditionals
text:
Testing pow() vs.¬†new_pow()

pow("ten", "two")

Error in x^v: non-numeric argument to binary operator

new_pow("ten", "two")

Error in new_pow("ten", "two"): The x argument value should be numeric.

new_pow(10, "two")

Error in new_pow(10, "two"): The v argument value should be numeric.

new_pow(10, 2)

[1] 100

title: Functions and conditionals
text:
Difference function
Write a function, called diff(), that takes the difference (subtracts) its first and second arguments. If you have time, try to include any necessary informative error messages.



‚àí+
05:00

title: Functions and conditionals
Functions and conditionals
Functions and conditionals
text:
Difference function
Testing:

diff(5, 2)

[1] 3

diff(2, 5)

[1] -3

diff("two", 5)

Error in diff("two", 5): The a argument value should be numeric.

title: Functions and conditionals
Functions and conditionals
Functions and conditionals
Functions and conditionals
Functions and conditionals
Functions and conditionals
Functions and conditionals
Functions and conditionals
Functions and conditionals
Functions and conditionals
text:
Conditional statements in a function

Let‚Äôs say you‚Äôre tired of R defaulting na.rm = FALSE when you take the mean of a variable. You could write a function with a different default!

title: Functions and conditionals
Functions and conditionals
Functions and conditionals
text:
Conditional statements in a function

nums <- c(1, 2, 3, NA, 5, 6)
my_mean(x = nums)

[1] 3.4

mean(x = nums)

[1] NA

mean(x = nums, na.rm = TRUE)

[1] 3.4

title: Functions and conditionals
Functions and conditionals
text:
A cautious mean

nums <- c(1, 2, 3, NA, 5, 6)
primes <- c(2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19, 23)

What will

my_mean(x = nums)
my_mean(x = primes)

output?



‚àí+
01:00

title: Functions and conditionals
text:
A cautious mean

my_mean(x = nums)

[1] "Watch out, you are removing NAs"


[1] 3.4

my_mean(x = primes)

[1] "We didn't remove any NAs"


[1] 11.11111

title: Functions and conditionals
text:
A cautious mean

my_mean(x = nums)

[1] "Watch out, you are removing NAs"


[1] 3.4

my_mean(x = primes)

[1] "We didn't remove any NAs"


[1] 11.11111

# What about `prime_mean`? 
prime_mean <- my_mean(x = primes)

[1] "We didn't remove any NAs"

title: Lecture Ticket 1
text:
Tasks

1. Install R and RStudio
As discussed in IFDAR, go to Posit‚Äôs website. Install R first, and then install RStudio.


2. Run your first R command
In the console, type in the following command and press Enter to run it:

rnorm(1)



3. Record your result
Come to class on Thursday with a piece of paper with your name on it that includes the result (it will be a number) from running rnorm(1) in task 2.
If you were unable to install R and RStudio and ran into issues, instead come to class with a piece of paper with your name on it that explains the issue you were having with installation.
